awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Precision Learning: Data-Driven Experimentation of Learning Theories using Internet-of-Videos
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project to study what works to help students learn more effectively in the context of the ASSISTments system. ASSISTments is an online system that provides both assistance to students and real time assessment data to teachers. ASSISTments now supports 100,000 students who have completed more than 12 million mathematics problems. The system uses teacher input and artificial intelligence to provide assistance to students who are attempting to solve mathematics problems. This project will increase the assistance provided by the teacher and machine learning by incorporating video suggestions, such as those produced by the Kahn academy, targeted to the needs of the student. The experimentation will take content from three Open Educational Resource textbooks that are openly licensed and free to schools.

More specifically, the researchers will identify a large collection of videos that address mathematics skills in the textbooks and will extract features of these videos including language complexity, speaking rate, and other features. These videos and features will be checked by both teachers and through a Mechanical Turk process for usability before they are presented to students. Additionally, the project will develop a suite of novel technologies for precision learning including fine grained video feature extraction, student feature learning from heterogeneous raw data, causal modeling, and fairness aware and causal relationship enhanced optimized personalized recommendation. The research will advance theoretical understanding of fundamental issues related to personalized learning and will enable data-driven experimentation of learning theories. Causal modeling will enable the researchers to learn the features of video that are correlated with learning effectiveness. 

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution Big Idea activity and is co-funded by the Division of Undergraduate Education and the Division of Research on Learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has accomplished three major milestones. Firstly, this project has integratedthe ability to display skill-related content to students using ASSISTments. For this project,students were given the option to request skill-related videos, but in the future, thecapacity to include things like web-based simulations, relevant text-based guides, or linksto other practice problems could be included as well. Through this integration of skill-relatedvideos, we were able to investigate the impact that providing students with the option torequest a skill-related video had on their performance (measured using whether or not theywere able to get the next problem in their assignment correct on their first try without anymore tutoring). We found that students were only interested in viewing a video 0.7% of thetime, and with such a low use, there was no statistically significant impact to providingstudents with skill-related videos. 

Beyond just offering skill-level videos, this project set out to personalize the tutoringprovided to students within ASSISTments. To accomplish this, we developed the AutomaticPersonalized Learning Service (APLS) which integrated reinforcement learning into theASSISTments platform at scale for any student using the platform. Through thedevelopment of this capacity, we have not only investigated the impact of attempting topersonalize the skill-related videos offered to students, but also the problem-specific hintsand explanations that were already in ASSISTments. The APLS was first used todemonstrate that using Thompson sampling, a multi-armed bandit algorithm that learns toestimate the expected next-problem correctness of students and recommends content inorder to maximize the expected next-problem correctness, was able to slightly out-performthe existing method of recommending a random related piece of tutoring to students.

Lastly, the APLS was used to evaluate a new multi-armed bandit algorithm, Dynamic LinearEpsilon Greedy (DLEG), which we developed in order to personalize content provided tostudents in a way that allowed for interpretable, unbiased, statistically reliable analyses tobe performed on the data afterward. DLEG was able to outperform existing multi-armedbandit algorithms in simulation and slightly out-performed random selection inASSISTments when recommending skill-related videos to students.

Moving forward, more popular skill-related content can be integrated into ASSISTments, theAPLS can continue to run randomized experiments comparing different recommendationalgorithms, and DLEG can be applied to any domain where one desires to learn over timefrom recommendations in a way that is both robust to changes in the relationships in thedata, and unbiased for statistical analysis.
